quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 8 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 8.7: Graphs of Secant and Cosecant
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Graphing reciprocal functions using helper curves

questions.question: Which function serves as the 'ghost' or helper graph for $y = \csc x$?
questions.explanation: Since cosecant is $1/\sin x$, we use the sine wave to determine its critical points and asymptotes.

questions.question: Where do the vertical asymptotes of $y = \sec x$ occur?
questions.explanation: Secant is undefined whenever its denominator, cosine, is zero ($x = \pi/2, 3\pi/2$, etc.).

questions.question: What is the range of the parent function $y = \csc x$?
questions.explanation: Cosecant values are always greater than or equal to 1 or less than or equal to -1.

questions.question: Where does the graph of $y = \csc x$ have a local minimum?
options: Where sin x has a local maximum
Where sin x has a local minimum
questions.explanation: The 'bottom' of the upward-opening U-shape in cosecant occurs at the 'top' of the sine wave.

questions.question: If $y = 3 \sec x$, what is the lowest positive y-value on the graph?
questions.explanation: The helper cosine graph has a max of 3. The secant U-shape starts there and goes up, making 3 the minimum for that branch.

questions.question: True or False: The graph of $y = \sec x$ has x-intercepts.
questions.explanation: Because the range is $(-\infty, -1] \cup [1, \infty)$, the graph never crosses the x-axis ($y=0$).

questions.question: How many vertical asymptotes does $y = \csc x$ have on the interval $[0, 2\pi]$?
questions.explanation: Sine is zero at $0$, $\pi$, and $2\pi$. Cosecant has asymptotes at all three locations.

questions.question: Which of these functions is symmetric about the y-axis (Even)?
questions.explanation: Since Cosine is even, its reciprocal Secant is also even.

questions.question: If you shift the 'ghost' sine wave, what happens to the cosecant graph?
options: The asymptotes and U-shapes shift exactly the same way.
questions.explanation: The reciprocal function is 'tethered' to its partner; any transformation applied to the sine wave applies to the cosecant graph.

scoreMessages.90: Reciprocal Master! You used those ghost graphs perfectly.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Just remember: Asymptotes go where the helper hits the midline.
scoreMessages.50: Try drawing the sine wave first—it makes graphing cosecant much easier.
scoreMessages.0: Review the relationship between sin/csc and cos/sec.
